subject: Help getting software
msgSnippet: I m happy to see that this group consists of a lot of computer literate posters. I need help in setting up my computer so I can read and compose Quickscript. I
messageBody:
I'm happy to see that this group consists of a lot of computer literate
posters.

I need help in setting up my computer so I can read and compose
Quickscript. I am typing on a Mac which has 10.3. I am using Thuderbird
as my email viewer, but I can easily switch. To compose text in
Quickscript, I use MS Word (yuck!) simply because I didn't have to
configure it. I simply downloaded the Kingsley font, double clicked on
the .ttf file, which installed the font. The font was then available in
Word as well as Firefox.

I also have a linux box, but I don't really want to use this, simply
because the monitor is so darn big, and I like to just have one computer
in our apartment, my girlfriend's laptop. I prefer the linux box and
know how to write complicated scripts to convert text. (I wrote an
script rtf2xml, available at sourceforge.) I know about different types
of encoding and working with unicode.

As a first step, I would like to set up latex so I can write in
Quickscript. I don't think that should pose a herculean challenge. I
know I have to convert the ttf file to a font metrics, install the font
metrics in the right TeX folder, and then in the LaTeX file tell LaTeX
to use this font. Has anyone done this? Adding fonts in LaTeX--though
not herculean--never proceeds easily.

If posters know of a better way of composing text besides LaTeX, I would
like to hear. I know that even if I get the Fonts installed in LaTeX,
when I type a document, rather than Seeing Quicksript characters I will
see their ASCII counterparts (F wil sI His).

Thanks

Paul
